_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Loop 360 Municipal Utility District
EPA Risk Management Plan - Executive Summary
August 2006

1.0   Owner/Operator

The Loop 360 Water Treatment Plant is owned by Loop 360 Water Supply Corporation and operated by ECO Resources, Inc. The RMP incorporates the release prevention, emergency response, and training provisions of both the owner and operator, since these two entities coordinate implementation of on-site procedures to ensure that employees are properly prepared to prevent and respond to emergencies.

2.0   Stationary Source Description

This source is a 4.6 million gallons per day water supply corporation/water treatment plant that provides potable water for the Loop 360 Corporation service area. One of the components of the treatment plant is disinfection of the water by chlorination.  This site is located in an area where the terrain consists of relatively steep hills.

3.0   Regulated Substances

The only regulated substance present at this facility is chlorine gas, which is delivered in 150 lbs cylinders, and is not to exceed 18 cylinders.

4.0  Release Scenarios 
 
Methodology given in the RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance was used to determine worst and alternative case release scenarios.  The model RMP*Comp Version 1.07 was used with default weather conditions for worst case and neutral conditions.

5.0   Accidental Release Administrative Controls and Mitigative Measures

The site is subject to the requirements of OSHA 1910.120 and 1910.138 and qualifies as a Program 3 Risk Management Plan submittal.  It is the policy of the Loop 360 Water Supply Corporation and ECO Resources, Inc. to fully comply with OSHA and Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) regulations regarding the storage and use of hazardous materials.

No engineered passive controls are in place for a chlorine release from this site.  The chlorine transfer and feed stem will only operate under a vacuum.  If the vacuum is broken (due to a line break or leak), the valve at the chlori

ne storage cylinder automatically closes to prevent a release.  There are chlorine gas monitors near the chlorine gas system that provide direct reading and sound alarms at the operations building.  ECO Resources, Inc. has emergency equipment, leak repair kit, and employee training is provided.  A self-contained breathing apparatus is kept at the facility for use by personnel responding to a leak.  There are emergency procedures in place for stopping leaks and for notification of local authorities and emergency response teams. 

6.0   Five-year Accident History

There have been no accidents or releases at this site resulting in injuries or property damage.

7.0   Emergency Response Program

Upon discovery of a leak by an employee or local resident report or via the chlorine gas monitor/alarm system, ECO Resources, Inc. notifies the local chlorine response team and the facility emergency contact.  On-site response time is 30 minutes or less.  If the response team determines that 10 pounds of chlorine have been released, or if there is a potential health or off-site health threat, the proper authorities are notified immediately.  The response team will also take immediate steps to shut down the system and stop/repair the source of the release.

8.0   Changes to Improve Safety

No changes to improve the safety of this site are currently pending or being implemented.  There are no recommended changes at this time.
